fields.description: When you create a new autoscaling launch-config and than create a new autoscaling group against that lanuch-config with the desired-capacity and maxixmum-cpacity > ec2:quota-vminstancenumber the first time it will honor the quota and launch the number of instances allowed and log a quota exceeded error in cloud-error.log. If you then delete the autoscaling-group and create it again using the exact same command it will not log a quota exceeded error and will launch all instances even if they exceed the quota.
fields.summary: euscale-create-auto-scaling-group does not always honor ec2:quota-vminstancenumber

comments.body:
To Reproduce:
Create account, directory, uploadpolicy (attached hyd-quota.txt), keypair, launch-config, auto-scaling-group
{code}
euare-accountcreate -a hyderabad
mkdir hyderabad
cd hyderabad
euca_conf --cred-account hyderabad --cred-user admin --get-credentials hyderabad.zip
unzip hyderabad.zip
chmod 600 *
euare-accountuploadpolicy -a hyderabad -p hyd-quota -f hyd-quota.txt   
source ~/hyderabad/eucarc
euca-create-keypair hyderabad > hyderabad.private
chmod 600 hyderabad.private
euscale-create-launch-config HydLaunch -t m1.small --key hyderabad --group default --image emi-227117a7
euscale-create-auto-scaling-group -l HydLaunch -m 1 -M 3 --desired-capacity 3 -z PARTI00 HydScaling
{code}
The above launches only two instances as expected, the Quota was Honored and quota error was logged to cloud-error.log
Now delete the auto-scaling-group and re-create it, you will see that this time 3 instances get started and no quota error is logged.
{code}
euscale-delete-auto-scaling-group HydScaling --force-delete
euscale-create-auto-scaling-group -l HydLaunch -m 1 -M 3 --desired-capacity 3 -z PARTI00 HydScaling
{code}
Attached hyd-quota.txt to use for reproduction of this issue.

[~sjones] Should the account quota  "ec2:quota-vminstancenumber" supercede the euscale-create-auto-scaling-group  "--max-size" . What should have the final word on the maximum number of instances allowed to run in an auto-scaling-group?

[~mmunn1], the auto scaling service uses the ec2 service to run instances. The accounts instance limit for the ec2 service should restrict the number of instances launched via auto scaling. Note that any per-user quota should not impact auto scaling, only the account quota.

{code}
Code Review Request : EUCA-9729 euscale-create-auto-scaling-group does not always honor ec2:quota-vminstancenumber

branch   : dev/mmunn1/EUCA-9729

diff     :  git show --color d06469abb26f8b5018c3c8d41c7ad0fdd10e3539

Summary  : The quota-vminstancenumber is not always honored due to a race condition in    runAllocatorSafely specifically the updating of the usageValue in PolicyEngineImpl.processQuotas( List<Authorization> quotas, String action, String resourceType, String resourceName, Long quantity )

Solution : Synchronize the call to AdmissionControl.runAllocatorSafely in AdmissionControl.RunAdmissionControl.apply(Allocation allocInfo)

Unit test: described in comments, I have create a Eutester testcase for this issue at: /eutester/testcases/cloud_admin/4-0/EUCA-9729
{code}
[~mmunn1], the right solution is likely to account for ResourceState from CountVmInstances.

[~sjones] I think we might run into the same problem here, where the count would not be updated until the resource was allocated?  What am I missing here, I am not sure where you would run CountVmInstances after the vm resource was allocated and before the quota was validated?
[~mmunn1], CountVmInstances should include pending resources (less the number currently being allocated), the quota check itself accounts for the number of resources currently being allocated.

[~sjones]  The "quota check" is the issue as the quantity to be allocated is always '1' for auto scaling instances. If you run euca-run-instances -n 3 the quantity passed into the quota check is '3' and so all instances are accounted for. In the case of auto-scaling, the quantity passed in is always '1' and the quota check is run 'n' times for 'n' instances to be scaled up. The quota check can be run several times before the first instance is allocated and so it is not taken into account during the subsequent quota check, this is the race condition that I address with my proposed fix.

[~mmunn1], cluster resources are safely allocated (ResourceState#requestResourceAllocation) prior to any quota check (RestrictedTypes#allocateUnitlessResources) we just ignore these allocations when evaluating the current instance resource usage (CountVmInstances)

[~sjones] That is exactly the problem, when runAllocatorSafely is run in quick succession the usage has not been updated before the next Quota check, and will allow allocations that exceed the quota. I do not understand how CountVmInstances would help. See PolicyEngineImpl.processQuotas, What am I missing?

[~mmunn1], CountVmInstances is the QuantityMetricFunction for instances used from VmInstanceNumberQuotaKey to determine the current usage. CountVmInstances currently only counts instances that are persistent, not ones that were just allocated (via ResourceState#requestResourceAllocation)
[~sjones] Ok, now I see what you are saying I need to modify CountVmInstances to include the new allocations. Sorry for the confusion. I will give it a try.

[~sjones] I do not see any reliable way to get the number of just allocated instances in CountVmInstances until they are in fact persisted? Any pointers on how to do this would be greatly appreciated.

[~mmunn1], I think the right approach is for the resource allocation (ResourceState#requestResourceAllocation) to occur within the allocateUnitlessResource callback. For 4.0.2 it might be OK to modify  VmInstanceNumberQuotaKey to ignore the number of resources requested (since that amount is already reflected due to the currently pending resources), but you'd need to check if there is anywhere else that VmInstanceNumberQuotaKey is used to ensure that is safe.

[~sjones] Ignoring the number of resources requested will not resolve the issue for autoscaling  where we are allowing more instances to start than the quota calls for because in this case pending is always '1'  until another allocation is persisted. The quota is working correctly for "euca-run-instances -n n " where 'n' is passed as the quantity to VmInstanceNumberQuotaKey and ignoring that will break the quota validation for this use case. I think the  (ResourceState#requestResourceAllocation) to occur within the allocateUnitlessResource callback may the only way to go other than synchronizing the runAllocatorSafely, which is a potential bottleneck.
I have created a eutester for this issue /eutester/testcases/cloud_admin/4-0/euca9729

From Steve:
The fix potentially impacts quotas for snapshots, images, security
groups, ssh keys, auto scaling launch configurations, auto scaling
groups, auto scaling policies, and elbs as well as just instances. I
think the risk here is minimal (and any issues are unlikely to be
specific to a resource type)

The fix would also expose any existing issues where pending resource
tokens for instances were not rolled back promptly on run-instances
error. This could mean users would not be able to run instances until
those tokens expired (15 minutes by default). I'm not aware of any cases
where this would occur.

Fix Verified

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.0.2
Release     : 0.0.22272.60.20140924git25cf699.el6

Verified manually and with the eutester test (which needed some tweaks to run) Did not see any issues with other quotas in manual testing.
